facts: The oldest known written story is the Epic of Gilgamesh, recorded on clay tablets in ancient Mesopotamia over 4,000 years ago.
Many ancient books were written on papyrus or parchment scrolls, and the codex (a bound book with pages) became popular in the Roman Empire because it was easier to flip through.
Johannes Gutenberg’s printing press in the 1400s made it possible to create many copies of a book faster and cheaper than copying by hand.
A library does not just store books; it also helps people find reliable information, learn new skills, and explore different points of view.
A book’s table of contents, index, and glossary are tools that help readers locate topics, definitions, and important details quickly.
Books are translated into other languages so stories and ideas can travel across countries, and translators often adjust phrases to keep the meaning clear for new readers.
The ISBN (International Standard Book Number) is a unique code that helps bookstores and libraries identify the exact edition and format of a book.
sources_hint: For checking accuracy, look up Gutenberg and printing history (reputable museum or encyclopedia sources), the Epic of Gilgamesh (academic or museum references), and ISBN information (official ISBN agency sites).
